nodes.text: K-nearest neighbors (KNN) can be used to accurately predict heart disease from clinical and demographic patient data

Dataset comprises clinical and demographic features including age, sex, chest pain type, resting blood pressure, serum cholesterol, fasting blood sugar, resting ECG, maximum heart rate achieved, exercise-induced angina, oldpeak, slope, ca, thal, and a binary target for heart disease
KNN is applied as a nonparametric, instance based supervised classifier using distance metrics (Euclidean) and majority voting among K neighbors
Data preprocessing steps include feature selection to detect most relevant features and weighting strategies to address class imbalance
Model evaluation uses cross validation and metrics including sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, and AUC-ROC; experiments repeated three times with K set to 10 and average reported
Assumption that labeled historical patient records reliably indicate presence or absence of heart disease and that features chosen capture risk factors
Visualization via histograms performed for each numerical column to inspect distributions
Observed class counts show 303 individuals identified as prone to heart disease and males have higher diagnosed counts than females in the dataset
K choice and distance metric selection affect classifier performance; odd K values preferred to avoid ties and K tradeoff exists between overfitting and noise
KNN requires careful preprocessing such as feature scaling and missing data handling and is computationally expensive at classification time
Confusion matrix counts used: True Positive 38, False Positive 10, False Negative 7, True Negative 45
Using the confusion matrix counts, overall accuracy computed as (38+45)/(38+10+7+45) = 83 percent
Authors report KNN exhibits promising predictive performance for heart disease with high accuracy and high AUC-ROC values and provide feature importance analysis to interpret contributing factors
Conclusion claim that KNN can aid risk assessment and early detection, potentially improving diagnostic accuracy and patient outcomes when integrated with medical datasets
